REDUCING TESTING REQUIREMENTS TO THE FEDERAL MINIMUM: New information was released today by the Georgia Department of Education. See below.

"In keeping with Senate Bill 367, which was signed into law in July, Georgia has eliminated half of the Georgia Milestones End-of-Course tests required of high school students.

State School Superintendent Richard Woods and the State Board of Education jointly adopted a resolution on August 27 identifying the Georgia Milestones EOCs that will be eliminated: Geometry/Analytic Geometry, Ninth Grade Literature and Composition, Physical Science, and Economics.

Georgia has now seen the largest reduction in standardized testing in state history, going from 32 state-required assessments in 2015 to 19 beginning this school year. SB 367, which was championed by Governor Kemp and Superintendent Woods, also removed the fifth-grade social studies Georgia Milestones assessment, reducing Georgia elementary-school testing to the federal minimum."

TESTING WAIVERS: State leaders received a letter this week from Secretary Betsy DeVos stating that the U.S. Department of Education does NOT plan to grant federal testing waivers for the 2020-21 school year.

So, to comply with federal requirements, the Bartow County School System may be required to administer Georgia Milestones. Additional details will be released in the weeks ahead.

"We cannot control the federal testing requirement, but we can control its high-stakes components. It is time to be bold.

To our districts, families, educators, and students: don’t worry about the tests. Given the unique environment we are in, they are neither valid nor reliable measures of academic progress or achievement.

I repeat: do not worry about the tests. Worry about meeting the students and teachers where they are. Worry about a safe and supportive restart. Worry about the well-being of your students and teachers. Worry about doing what’s right." - State School Superintendent Richard Woods

JOB READY: Jeremiah, our Project SEARCH intern and former Cass High School graduate and mascot, entered CHS today with a new title: EMPLOYEE!

Congratulations, Jeremiah! We are lucky to have you back on campus!

Read below to learn more about Project SEARCH.

The goal for each student participant in Project SEARCH is competitive employment. The program provides real-life work experience, combined with training in employability and independent living skills to help youths make successful transitions from school to productive adult life. The Project SEARCH model involves an extensive period of training and career exploration, innovative adaptations, long-term job coaching, and continuous feedback from teachers, job coaches, and employers. As a result, at the completion of the training program, students seek employment in nontraditional, complex and rewarding jobs.

GOING GAGA FOR 'GAGA BALL'

Thanks to a Bartow Education Foundation grant and the handiwork of John Stanfield, the husband of fourth-grade teacher Jennifer Stanfield, this GaGa Ball arena was built! And, if you build it, they will come!

Students of all ages and abilities will use the arena to play the fast-paced Dodgeball-like sport called GaGa Ball and also participate in academic activities like math (area, perimeter) and sight word fluency.

GaGa Ball promotes teamwork, communication, hand-eye coordination, and socialization.

Additionally, regular participation in physical activity and higher levels of physical fitness have been linked to improved academic performance and brain functions, such as attention and memory. These brain functions are the foundation for learning.

In addition to the 15,000 masks and 2,000 gallons of hand sanitizer we've already received from the state, among many other materials, the Bartow County School System will receive the following shipment soon from Georgia Emergency Management and Homeland Security Agency.

Hand Sanitizer Stations – 114
Clear Face Masks – 708
3-ply Disposable Face Masks – 8,400
Fogger Machines – 24
Fogger Solution – 96

The majority of the supplies are distributed within all 20 Bartow County schools based on student counts. Transportation, Central Registration, and Central Office have also received a portion of the materials from round one and two.

Special thanks to Shaw Industries for graciously using its resources to deliver these materials to 17 school districts in Northwest Georgia!

BCSS STUDENT SUCCESS: Have your children excitedly told you about how they get rewarded for postive behavior in school? Maybe they get Dojo points or other forms of "currency" to cash in for items like ice cream or toys?!

It's all a part of our Positive Behavior Interventions and Supports (PBIS) model.

"PBIS is a proactive approach that schools use to improve school safety and promote positive behavior. The focus of PBIS is prevention, not punishment."

This week, our elementary schools were given a large assortment of incentives to add to their PBIS stores. Included were notebooks, backpacks, toys, tiaras, and much more! Donations were made by Dollar General and the Bartow Collaborative. The Rotary Club of Etowah helped to organize everything.

Our students are excited to demonstrate what it means to be Bartow's Best by making good choices and being kind to others while working hard in school.

Special THANK YOU to our great community for supporting our students, once again!

SURVEY SAYS: The results from our Digital Learning Days Survey are in!

We sifted through each response collected from teachers, parents, and students and plan to utilize the information now in preparation for possible Digital Learning Days in the future.

While it's still very early in the reopening process, it is our expectation right now that school will start on schedule, August 5, 2020.

However, in the event of a health or weather emergency, students and teachers will soon be able to access Microsoft Teams, a video conferencing platform that allows for live, secure online classrooms and virtual office hours. More information will be released at a later date.

Additionally, we're looking into screencasting software so teachers can communicate more effectively through quick, clear "how-to" videos. The software lets you capture your screen and use narration to customize a video. Again, more details to come.

Thank you to those who offered feedback. You've helped streamline the DLD process!

post_text: BRAVE CONQUERS FEAR: We can no longer call Brooklyn Grace our very own Pine Log Pre-K Powerhouse! That's because she graduated! Check out this follow-up story 11 Alive did on Brooklyn Grace. You'll recognize that sweet voice and enjoy seeing a little bit of her graduation celebration filled with beautiful balloons and braille.
shared_text:
Cheryl Preheim
May 26 at 10:37 PM ·

Brooklyn Grace has a way to make any day a little brighter. She sent a video message that made my day. “Hello Miss Cheryl!” She said in her sweet voice. She was dressed up in a red dress and pink high top sneakers. “It’s been a little while since we talked.”

Brooklyn Grace is positive and energetic. She was born blind but is an incredible ability to recognize the beauty in people and life despite a long list of medical challenges.

Her mom Lexie Hunt said, “We found out about her health condition when she was 7 weeks old.”

Brooklyn Grace never gives up.

“I’ve got some good news to tell you.” She smiled to the camera. “I graduated from Pre-K!” She celebrated her 4-year-old graduation at home with a beautiful banner and balloons around her. And she got the best gift ever. “And I got a new puppy named Copper.” He is a beautiful black puppy who loves to snuggle in her lap.

Brooklyn Grace graces shows us what it means to be the sunshine to someone – in any circumstance.

“I hope your family is doing well.” She said. “And please don’t catch the corona.”

Brave Conquers Fear

As parents and students drive off campus, the Colonel Family and Cass community will have one last chance to say goodbye and thank you.

If you would like to participate, please arrive on campus at 7:30 pm. You will then be shown where to park. You are also allowed/encouraged to bring signs, flags, and anything else you’d like to have while waving/cheering each family that passes.

Join us in congratulating Bartow's best!

GHP CANCELLED: The Governor's Honors Program at Berry College will be cancelled this summer for the first time since its inception in 1964 due to concerns associated with COVID-19. This affects three finalists from Bartow County Schools.

"It is a tremendous disappointment to hear that it has been cancelled for the first time in program history, but we understand these are unprecedented times, and the safety, health, and well-being of our students is paramount. We support any decision made to protect our children and uphold the integrity of the exclusive program.

To think of the countless hours of preparation our finalists and alternates endured is heartbreaking; knowing some rising seniors may never get that unique opportunity to showcase their talents at GHP is devastating. However, we, as a system, find comfort in knowing the program’s leadership team, instructors, and partners are crafting a plan right now to honor rising senior finalists and provide an opportunity for rising junior finalists to be admitted to the program next summer." - BCSS GHP Coordinator Paula Camp

Congratulations to Sebastian Diaz-Cruz for winning the Exceptional Children's Week - Technological Brilliance Award! Sebastian attends Kingston Elementary and was nominated by his teacher, Ms. King who said, "When I met Sebastian at the beginning of the year, he struggled to communicate. He used many gestures and any pictures I had to offer in the classroom. After getting a communication device in December, I have seen Sebastian flourish in his communication. I love seeing his face light up realizing he has the power now to communicate his needs and wants more effectively. When offered a selection of pictures to choose for free time activities, Sebastian has quickly learned that he can always go to his device when what he wants isn't available in my collection of pictures. When reading books in class, he uses his device to share information and tell his teachers what he sees in the pictures. I'm so proud of Sebastian's progress in using technology to communicate and I'm excited to see what more he can accomplish with his newfound voice."

With a capacity of around 6,000 people, LakePoint Sports can hold roughly three times as many people than a high school gym. That means the Bartow County School System can include more families in the commencement celebration and provide proper seating arrangements that follow state and local health department guidelines. The air-conditioned facility and free parking will also assist with providing our families a safe viewing for the event.

While we understand our students’ connection to their schools, we hope these alternative arrangements during an uncertain time, bring hope and happiness to our seniors. They have accomplished so much during their time with us, and we want to honor them to the best of our ability this summer!

EXCEPTIONAL EDUCATION ANNUAL AWARDS: The 2ND Annual Director’s Choice Award is presented to Kim Chester, our parent mentor!

Congratulations Kim! - Tania Amerson, Executive Director for Exceptional Education

STRONGER TOGETHER: During trying times, superheroes emerge. They might not wear bright capes or get noticed by all, but we see them shining bright and strong in a community that desperately needs them now more than ever.

Meet Candace Bowman, our school nutrition manager at Cass Middle School. She's currently working next door at Hamilton Crossing Elementary School, one of four meal distribution sites in Bartow County.

Recently, while handing a bag of food to a mother and her child, she noticed an infant in need of formula. So, she rallied her own troops and provided food for the baby.

Ms. Candace is also instrumental in making sure children are fed through the Backpack Buddies initative, and she can be seen knocking on doors and honking horns, all in an effort to feed neighborhood families with leftover meals from distribution sites.

Thank you, Ms. Candace. You're a true school nutrition superhero who is much needed and appreciated in our community!

INSIDE LOOK: Ever wonder what teachers do during Professional Learning or PL days, like the one we had this Wednesday during students' winter break? Well, at Woodland High School, it consisted of teacher leaders conducting professional development sessions throughout the building on topics like, "Characteristics of Gifted Learners," or "Increasing Student Achievement through Effective Classroom Management." #RightWork #BCSSSuccess

"These sessions were truly 'by teachers and FOR teachers.' I am incredibly proud of not only our guiding coalition and teacher leaders but ALL our staff who entered into these local sessions with the intention of improving practice and student outcomes." WHS Principal David Stephenson

“It was an enjoyable experience to learn from each other. I know that we are all teachers, but it is impressive to see the others in action. It makes one truly appreciate the work being done around our school.” - Catherine Johnson, Teacher

She provides encouragement and support and is oftentimes her students' biggest cheerleader. She takes on any task that is asked of her with a smile and positive attitude. She arrives early and stays late doing anything she can to make Woodland High School a better place for students. We are so fortunate to have Ms. Black at WHS!" - WHS Principal David Stephenson

Each STAR student selected a STAR teacher who has been influential in his or her journey towards academic excellence.
